title: Protocol to assess the tolerogenic properties of adoptively transferred dendritic cells during murine experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Induction of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE)
Timing: 1–2 h for EAE induction
Timing: 30 min–1 h for Scoring (depending on mouse numbers)
Induction of EAE.
Prepare MOG injection solution and pertussis injection solution as described earlier.
Restrain mouse in restrainer.
Locate the right flank and apply 70% ethanol with a pipet tip to wet the fur and localize the injection site (see Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
    Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
  
Methods video S1. Subcutaneous injection of MOG/CFA emulsion for EAE induction, related to step 1
Subcutaneously inject mouse with 75 μL of MOG-emulsion and carefully remove the needle (see Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Repeat at left flank.
Critical: Successful subcutaneous injections should result in visible bolus shaped depots under the skin. No significant amount of MOG/CFA emulsion should leak after the injection.
Draw pertussis injection solution in a 1 mL syringe.
Inject each mouse i.p. with 100 μL.
2 days later repeat the preparation and injection of the pertussis solution.
EAE scoring.
Starting on day 7 post EAE induction, examine mice daily for weight loss and clinical symptoms.
Classify clinical symptoms according to the following criteria. See Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1941_6.csv
Note: The disease kinetics (day of onset, peak, remission phase varies between experiments, mouse strains, laboratories. However, a successful immunization regimen should result in 80%–100% disease incidence. Typically, mice start to lose weight and develop the first symptoms within 7–12 days after EAE induction (Mendel et al., 1995[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Barthelmes et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1].

Note: Some mice may develop skin lesions at the injection site. Small ulcers usually heal within a few days without treatment but if necessary, mice can be treated with antibiotic ointment. However, in rare cases some mice develop larger skin lesions (approximately 2 cm diameter) which are characterized by complete hair loss and redness. Mice with this type of lesion rarely develop EAE symptoms and should be excluded from the experiment.
Critical: Provide mice with wet food and easily accessible water on the cage floor as soon as they show first signs of paralysis. If severe dehydration is observed, mice should be injected with glucose-supplemented saline or Ringer’s solution.
Critical: Scoring should be done in a blinded manner and ideally always by the same person.

Methods video S2. Overview of clinical scores in EAE bearing mice, related to step 2
Bone marrow isolation and differentiation of bone-marrow-derived dendritic cells (BM-DCs)
Timing: 1–2 h Bone marrow isolation
Timing: 7 days Differentiation
Isolation of bones.
Humanely euthanize mice according to ethical guidelines and spray with 70% ethanol to sterilize skin.
Note: We usually use 8–12 week old mice for BM-DC generation.
Cut open abdominal skin with scissors and remove skin from the whole hind leg by pulling out the leg from its skin layers.
Dislocate the hip joint without breaking it, remove the whole hind-leg and place it in a falcon with fresh PBS.
Critical: Bones should not get broken during the isolation otherwise bone marrow cells might get contaminated.
Perform all following steps in a tissue culture-hood.
Isolation of bone marrow cells (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1941-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Critical steps of bone marrow isolation and BM-DC differentiation

Take hind legs out of tube and quickly dip in a falcon filled with 70% ethanol. Place bones on a sterile paper towel.
Remove the paw and subsequently try to remove as much muscle and connective tissue as possible.
Place the bones in a 6-well dish filled with sterile PBS (finish bone isolation of all mice/genotypes needed for the experiment).
Prepare 50 mL falcons and place a 70 μM cell strainer on them.
Pre-wet strainer with 2 mL of PBS.
Take the tibia and femur with a sterile forceps and trim both ends using sterilized scissors to open up the bones.
Take a 5 mL syringe and fill it with 5 mL sterile PBS and attach a 27-gauge needle to it.
Hold the tibia/femur over the prepared strainer, insert the needle into the narrow end of the tibia/femur.
Flush the bone marrow onto the 70 μM strainer.
Carefully disrupt bone marrow chunks with the tip of the serological pipet and wash the strainer with 10 mL PBS or culture medium.
When no more red chunks are visible on the strainer, spin down cell suspension at 500 g for 5 min at room temperature.
A clear red visible pellet should be visible.
Discard the supernatant by inverting the falcon over a waste bottle.
Resuspend cell pellet in 1 mL of erythrocyte-lysis buffer, incubate for 5 min at room temperature.
Stop erythrocyte-lysis by adding 10 mL of culture medium.
Spin down cell suspension at 500 g for 5 min at room temperature. Pellet should be completely white. In case pellet remains red, erylysis should be repeated.
Discard the supernatant by inverting the falcon over a waste bottle.
Resuspend cell pellet in 10 mL of culture medium and count cells.
Start BM-DC differentiation.

Seed 5 × 106 cells in 10 mL culture medium in a 10 cm tissue-culture treated petri-dish with 20 ng/mL GM-CSF and 5 ng/mL IL-4.
Put dishes in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator.
Day 3: Add 5 mL of fresh culture media with 20 ng/mL GM-CSF and 5 ng/mL IL-4. Total volume of culture media is then 15 mL.
Optional: BM-DC generation also works from frozen bone-marrow, however in our experience the yield of fully-differentiated BM-DCs is decreased.
Harvest of fully differentiated BM-DCs and antigen loading
Timing: 5–6 h
Day 6–7: Harvest fully differentiated BM-DCs (troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]).
Check cell morphology and confluency under the microscope (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1941-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Quality control of antigen-loaded BM-DCs
(A and B) Morphology of BM-DC cultures during differentiation (A) and quality control of MOG35–55 loaded BM-DCs by flow cytometry (B). Scale bars = 500 μM, cells are gated for viable CD11c+ DCs and further assessed for their CD80, CD86, MHC-II, and MHC-I surface expression.
Carefully remove 6 mL of media directly from surface.
With the remaining media detach loosely attached cells by pipetting over the dish several times.
Critical: Post differentiation, do not use highly adherent cells as most of these cells do not represent mature BM-DCs (Helft et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]).
Transfer cell suspension in a 15 mL falcon and count cells.
Antigen loading of BM-DCs.
Spin down cell suspension at 500 g for 5 min at room temperature and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend 2 × 106 cells in 2 mL culture medium per well and plate in a 6 well plate.
Immediately add 10 μg/mL MOG35–55 (freshly thawed aliquot).
Note: Always plate a little more BM-DCs than needed. Not all cells can be recovered after scraping and additional suspension is needed for the dead volume of the syringe and BM-DC quality control.

Incubate cells for 5–6 h in a 37°C, 5%CO2 incubator.
Transfer of antigen-loaded DCs and quality control
Timing: 1 h
This step describes adoptive transfer of antigen loaded bone-marrow derived dendritic cells and their quality control. The quantity of cell transfers and the exact timing might be adapted depending on the biological question.
Harvest of MOG-loaded BM-DCs.
Visually check cells (upon antigen loading DCs usually loosely attach to the dish) under the microscope.
Gently detach DCs by using a cell scraper.
Transfer cell suspension into a 15 mL falcon.
Determine cell number.
Spin down cell suspension at 500 g for 5 min at room temperature and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend cells in sterile PBS at a concentration of 1 × 107 cells/mL. You will require 50 μL per mouse plus 100 μL excess volume if syringes with dead-volume are used.
Transfer cell suspension in an Eppendorf tube (2 mL or 5 mL) and store cells on ice until injections. Injections should be performed immediately.
Keep a cell aliquot for the quality control (step 12).
Transfer of cells.
Randomize mice across experimental groups/conditions.
Anaesthetize mice with isoflurane (2%–4% under constant oxygen flow).
Draw BM-DC cell suspension into a 1 mL syringe and mount a 27G needle.
Intravenously inject each mouse with 50 μL of the DC cell suspension via the retro-orbital sinusoid.
Critical: Injections should be performed as quick as possible to ensure an evenly suspended cell injection solution.
Note: The BM-DC transfer is also compatible with the use of in vivo blocking antibodies such as anti-PD-1. We usually inject blocking antibodies i.p. 2–4 h before mice receive the cell transfer. For further details please refer to (Vogel et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]).
Quality control of transferred BM-DCs.

Transfer approximately 0.5 × 106 cells in a 96-well plate for staining. Alternatively, cells can also be stained in a tube.
Prepare the DC quality control antibody staining mix (according to table in materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) in 1% FCS/PBS (including viability dye).
Centrifuge cells at 500 g for 5 min at room temperature and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 10 μL staining mix and incubate for 15 min at RT.
Add 180 μL of 1% FCS/PBS and centrifuge at 500 g for 5 min at RT.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend pellets in 150 μL 1% FCS/PBS.
Pause point: If cells cannot be analyzed on the same day, resuspend cells in 100 μL eBioscience fixation buffer and incubate for 15 min at RT. Spin cells at 500 g for 5 min at room temperature, discard the supernatant and resuspend in 150 μL 1% FCS/PBS. Cells can now be stored at 4°C in the dark for several days.
Acquire samples on FACS machine.
Harvest and processing of spleen and lymph nodes
Timing: 1–2 h
3 days after the last DC-transfer (day 17 post EAE induction), euthanize mice and process spleen and lymph nodes for flow cytometric analysis.
Prepare a 6-well plate, place a 70 μm strainer in each well and fill with 3 mL of sterile PBS. Put plate on ice.
Isolate spleen and inguinal lymph nodes of each mouse and place into a separate well.
Spleen processing.
By using the plunger from a 5 mL syringe, mash the spleen through the cell strainer.
Wash the strainer with 5 mL of PBS.
Discard the strainer.
Transfer splenocyte cell suspension into a 15 mL falcon.
Centrifuge cells at 500 g for 5 min at RT.
Decant the supernatant and resuspend pellet in 1 mL of erythrocyte-lysis buffer.

Incubate for 5 min at RT.
Fill up falcon to 10 mL with PBS and spin down cells at 500 g for 5 min at RT.
Decant supernatant and resuspend pellet in 10 mL PBS.
Critical: Remove cell clumps that usually form during erythrocyte-lysis.
Transfer 200 μL splenocyte suspension into a 96-well plate and continue with “flow cytometry staining”.
Lymph node processing.
By using the plunger from a 5 mL syringe, mash the lymph nodes through the cell strainer.
Wash the strainer with 5 mL of PBS.
Discard the strainer.
Transfer cell suspension into a 15 mL falcon.
Centrifuge cells at 500 g for 5 min at RT.
Decant supernatant and resuspend pellet in 5 mL PBS.
Transfer 200 μL lymph node suspension into a 96-well plate and continue with “flow cytometry staining”.
Flow cytometry staining
Timing: 2–3 h
Prepare antibody staining mix (according to table in materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) in 1% FCS/PBS (including viability dye).
Note: Include single staining controls for setting up a proper compensation. For critical surface markers, exhibiting gradual expression patterns such as CD25, include fluorescence minus one (FMO) controls to ensure proper gating during data analysis.
Centrifuge 96-well plates with spleen and lymph node cells at 500 g for 5 min at RT and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 10 μL antibody staining mix and incubate for 15 min at RT in the dark.
Wash cells by adding 180 μL 1% FCS/PBS to each well.
Centrifuge plate at 500 g for 5 min at RT and discard supernatant.
Prepare 1× Fix/Perm buffer by adding 1 part Fix/Perm concentrate and 3 parts Fix/Perm Diluent from the FoxP3 Fix/Perm Buffer Kit (see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]).
Resuspend pellets in 80 μL Fix/Perm buffer and incubate for 30 min at RT in the dark.

Prepare 1× Perm buffer by diluting 1 part 10× Perm buffer from the FoxP3 Fix/Perm Buffer Kit (see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) in 9 parts ddH2O.
Wash cells by adding 100 μL 1× Perm buffer to each well.
Centrifuge plate at 500 g for 5 min at RT and discard supernatant.
Note: Cells are hardly visible after fixation.
Resuspend cells in 150 μL 1× Perm buffer and incubate for 5 min at RT in the dark.
Centrifuge plate at 500 g for 5 min at RT and discard supernatant.
Pause point: If cells cannot be analyzed on the same day, resuspend cells in 1× Perm Buffer and store O/N on 4°C in the dark. Resume with intracellular staining on the next day.
Prepare the intracellular antibody staining mix (according to table in materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) in 1× Perm Buffer.
Resuspend cells in 10 μL intracellular antibody staining mix and incubate for 30 min at RT in the dark.
Note: For staining of nuclear antigens such as FoxP3, always include an isotype control.
Wash cells by adding 150 μL 1× Perm buffer.
Centrifuge plate at 500 g for 5 min at RT and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 150 μL 1% FCS/PBS.
Acquire samples on FACS machine.
We used a Cytoflex S flow cytometer (Beckman Coulter) for our studies and analyzed the data using CytExpert and FlowJo.
